page.title: 12Ravenfield Interview cont.
page.content: {Was food any different? Mr. Edwards, who owned the farm opposite Ravenfield school came round with zinc lined milk cans and ladled pint measures into our jugs. To keep milk fresh we kept it in terracotta pots, and jugs. Meat was wrapped in a cloth and then put in a mesh holder. Tinned food was very rare; bully beef (corned beef) and fruit. In 1935 they didn't have crisps, and a ha'penny worth of sweets normally lasted a week. Fish & chips cost 3d. {Is Ravenfield a better place to live {now than then? In some peoples mind it is not; there is not so much social life, but for young people, it is better now because there are tennis courts, a youth club and other facilities. We entertained ourselves in 1935, ran a garden fete every year and knew each other well.
